content.text: The student measures the potential difference \(V_{1}\) across the resistor \(\mathbf{R}_{\mathbf{A}}\) and the current \(I_{1}\) in the circuit. Figs. 1.2 and 1.3 show the voltmeter and ammeter scales
On Fig. 1.4, draw a line for the needle on the ammeter to show the reading of 0.13A
Fig. 1.4
The student connects a resistor \(\mathbf{R}_{\mathbf{B}}\) in series with \(\mathbf{R}_{\mathbf{A}}\)
She measures the potential difference \(V_{2}\) across the two resistors \(\mathbf{R}_{\mathbf{A}}\) and \(\mathbf{R}_{\mathbf{B}}\) combined and the current \(I_{2}\) in the circuit
A student suggests that \(R_{3} = 3 \times R_{1}\)
State whether the results agree with this suggestion. Justify your answer by reference to the results
statement
justification
Another student suggests that the three resistors \(\mathbf{R}_{\mathbf{A}}, \mathbf{R}_{\mathbf{B}}\) and \(\mathbf{R}_{\mathbf{C}}\) each have the same value of resistance
Explain how you could use the circuit shown in Fig. 1.1 to check this suggestion
Complete the circuit diagram in Fig. 1.5 to show:
the three resistors connected in parallel
the voltmeter connected to measure the potential difference across the resistors
a variable resistor connected to control the current in all three resistors
The circuit in Fig. 1.5 could be used to determine the combined resistance of three resistors connected in parallel
Suggest a reason for connecting a variable resistor in the circuit
A student is investigating resistance using the circuit shown in Fig. 1.1
On Fig. 2.1, measure the distance \(v\) from the lens to the screen

On Fig. 2.1, measure the distance \(d\) from the illuminated object to the screen

The student obtains a sharply-focused image on the screen
Calculate \(V,\) the actual distance from the lens to the screen. Record the value of \(V\) in the first row of Table 2.1
Calculate \(D,\) the actual distance from the illuminated object to the screen. Record the value of \(D\) in the first row of the table
Calculate \(UV\) and record the result in the table
Fig. 2.1 is drawn \(1 / 10^{\text{th}}\) actual size
The student repeated the procedure with the lens at a distance \(U = 30.0 \text{cm}\) from the illuminated object. All the readings are recorded in the table
State **one** difference that you would expect to observe between the image formed on the screen when \(U = 20.0 \text{cm}\) and when \(U = 30.0 \text{cm}\)

content.text: Suggest two reasons why it may be difficult to obtain reliable results in this experiment
Suggest a suitable number of values for \(U.\)
Suggest a suitable range of values for \(U.\)
A student states that a more reliable value for the focal length is obtained if more values of \(U,\) \(V\) and \(D\) are collected, enabling a graph to be drawn of \(UV\) against \(D.\)
A student is determining the focal length \(f\) of a lens
Fig. 2.1 shows the apparatus used

A student is investigating whether the diameter of a pendulum bob affects the period of a pendulum. The period is the time taken for one complete oscillation of the pendulum. Fig. 3.1 shows a pendulum
Fig. 3.2 shows one complete oscillation
For each value of \(Q\), calculate \(\frac{1}{Q}\) and record the result in the table
Plot a graph of \(b / \text{cm}\) ( \(y\)-axis) against \(\frac{1}{Q} /\frac{1}{N}\) ( \(x\)-axis)
Determine the gradient \(G\) of the graph. Show clearly on the graph how you obtained the necessary information
Calculate the weight \(P\) of load \(\mathbf{P}\) using the equation \(P = \frac{G}{a}\) , where \(a = 19.8 \text{cm}\)
The student measures the weight \(P\) of load \(\mathbf{P}\) using a forcemeter. Fig. 4.2 shows the forcemeter
Write down the reading \(P\) shown on the forcemeter
The student has carried out the experiment with care and is expecting the two values of \(P\) in (c) and (d) to be the same
Suggest **two** reasons why the values of \(P\) may be different
A student is determining the weight of a load using a balancing method
Fig. 4.1 shows the apparatus used
The student places the metre rule on the pivot and adjusts its position so that the metre rule is as near as possible to being balanced
He places a load \(\mathbf{P}\) on the metre rule so that its centre is exactly at the \(30.0 \text{cm}\) mark
He records the distance \(a\) between \(\mathbf{P}\) and the pivot
He places a load \(\mathbf{Q}\) of weight \(Q = 1.0 \text{N}\) on the metre rule and adjusts the position of \(\mathbf{Q}\) so that the metre rule is as near as possible to being balanced
He measures the distance \(b\) between the centre of load \(\mathbf{Q}\) and the pivot

He repeats the procedure, with the load \(\mathbf{P}\) remaining at the \(30.0 \text{cm}\) mark, using \(Q\) values of \(2.0 \text{N}\), \(3.0 \text{N}\), \(4.0 \text{N}\) and \(5.0 \text{N}\). All the readings are recorded in Table 4.1
